column2: Chapter 32
column3: Chapter thirty two

column2: But the cold, severe glance with which he had looked at her when he came to tell her he was going had wounded her, and before he had started her peace of mind was destroyed.
column3: But the cold, severe glance with which he had looked at her when he came to tell her he was going had wounded her, and before he had started her peace of mind was destroyed.

column2: In solitude afterwards, thinking over that glance which had expressed his right to freedom, she came, as she always did, to the same point--the sense of her own humiliation.
column3: In solitude afterwards, thinking over that glance which had expressed his right to freedom, she came, as she always did, to the same point-the sense of her own humiliation.

column2: Not simply to go away, but to leave me.
column3: Not simply to go away, but to leave me.

column2: He has every right, and I have none.
column3: He has every right, and I have none.

column2: What has he done, though?...
column3: What has he done, though?...

column2: He looked at me with a cold, severe expression.
column3: He looked at me with a cold, severe expression.

column2: Of course that is something indefinable, impalpable, but it has never been so before, and that glance means a great deal," she thought.
column3: Of course that is something indefinable, impalpable, but it has never been so before, and that glance means a great deal," she thought.

column2: That glance shows the beginning of indifference.
column3: That glance shows the beginning of indifference.

column2: And though she felt sure that a coldness was beginning, there was nothing she could do, she could not in any way alter her relations to him.
column3: And though she felt sure that a coldness was beginning, there was nothing she could do, she could not in any way alter her relations to him.

column2: Just as before, only by love and by charm could she keep him.
column3: Just as before, only by love and by charm could she keep him.

column2: That means was divorce and marriage.
column3: That means was divorce and marriage.

column2: And she began to long for that, and made up her mind to agree to it the first time he or Stiva approached her on the subject.
column3: And she began to long for that, and made up her mind to agree to it the first time he or Stiva approached her on the subject.

column2: Absorbed in such thoughts, she passed five days without him, the five days that he was to be at the elections.
column3: Absorbed in such thoughts, she passed five days without him, the five days that he was to be at the elections.

column2: However hard she tried, she could not love this little child, and to feign love was beyond her powers.
column3: However hard she tried, she could not love this little child, and to feign love was beyond her powers.

column2: Towards the evening of that day, still alone, Anna was in such a panic about him that she decided to start for the town, but on second thoughts wrote him the contradictory letter that Vronsky received, and without reading it through, sent it off by a special messenger.
column3: Towards the evening of that day, still alone, Anna was in such a panic about him that she decided to start for the town, but on second thoughts wrote him the contradictory letter that Vronsky received, and without reading it through, sent it off by a special messenger.

column2: She dreaded a repetition of the severe look he had flung at her at parting, especially when he knew that the baby was not dangerously ill. But still she was glad she had written to him.
column3: She dreaded a repetition of the severe look he had flung at her at parting, especially when he knew that the baby was not dangerously ill. But still she was glad she had written to him.

column2: Let him weary of her, but he would be here with her, so that she would see him, would know of every action he took.
column3: Let him weary of her, but he would be here with her, so that she would see him, would know of every action he took.

column2: She was sitting in the drawing room near a lamp, with a new volume of Taine, and as she read, listening to the sound of the wind outside, and every minute expecting the carriage to arrive.
column3: She was sitting in the drawing room near a lamp, with a new volume of Taine, and as she read, listening to the sound of the wind outside, and every minute expecting the carriage to arrive.

column2: At last she heard not the sound of wheels, but the coachman's shout and the dull rumble in the covered entry.
column3: At last she heard not the sound of wheels, but the coachman's shout and the dull rumble in the covered entry.

column2: Even Princess Varvara, playing patience, confirmed this, and Anna, flushing hotly, got up; but instead of going down, as she had done twice before, she stood still.
column3: Even Princess Varvara, playing patience, confirmed this, and Anna, flushing hotly, got up; but instead of going down, as she had done twice before, she stood still.

column2: She suddenly felt ashamed of her duplicity, but even more she dreaded how he might meet her.
column3: She suddenly felt ashamed of her duplicity, but even more she dreaded how he might meet her.

column2: All feeling of wounded pride had passed now; she was only afraid of the expression of his displeasure.
column3: All feeling of wounded pride had passed now; she was only afraid of the expression of his displeasure.

column2: Then she thought of him, that he was here, all of him, with his hands, his eyes.
column3: Then she thought of him, that he was here, all of him, with his hands, his eyes.

column2: She heard his voice.
column3: She heard his voice.

column2: And forgetting everything, she ran joyfully to meet him.
column3: And forgetting everything, she ran joyfully to meet him.

column2: Well, how is Annie? he said timidly from below, looking up to Anna as she ran down to him.
column3: Well, how is Annie? he said timidly from below, looking up to Anna as she ran down to him.

column2: He was sitting on a chair, and a footman was pulling off his warm over-boot.
column3: He was sitting on a chair, and a footman was pulling off his warm over boot.

column2: Oh, she is better.
column3: Oh, she is better.

column2: She took his hand in both of hers, and drew it to her waist, never taking her eyes off him.
column3: She took his hand in both of hers, and drew it to her waist, never taking her eyes off him.

column2: Well, I'm glad, he said, coldly scanning her, her hair, her dress, which he knew she had put on for him.
column3: Well, I'm glad, he said, coldly scanning her, her hair, her dress, which he knew she had put on for him.

column2: Well, I'm glad.	Well, I'm glad.
And are you well?" he said, wiping his damp beard with his handkerchief and kissing her hand.
column3: And are you well?" he said, wiping his damp beard with his handkerchief and kissing her hand.

column2: Never mind, she thought, "only let him be here, and so long as he's here he cannot, he dare not, cease to love me."
column3: Never mind, she thought, "only let him be here, and so long as he's here he cannot, he dare not, cease to love me."

column2: What am I to do?	What am I to do?
I couldn't sleep....
column3: I couldn't sleep....

column2: When he's here I never take it--hardly ever."
column3: When he's here I never take it-hardly ever."

column2: He told her about the election, and Anna knew how by adroit questions to bring him to what gave him most pleasure--his own success.
column3: He told her about the election, and Anna knew how by adroit questions to bring him to what gave him most pleasure-his own success.

column2: She told him of everything that interested him at home; and all that she told him was of the most cheerful description.
column3: She told him of everything that interested him at home; and all that she told him was of the most cheerful description.

column2: She said:
column3: She said:

column2: Tell me frankly, you were vexed at getting my letter, and you didn't believe me?
column3: Tell me frankly, you were vexed at getting my letter, and you didn't believe me?

column2: As soon as she had said it, she felt that however warm his feelings were to her, he had not forgiven her for that.
column3: As soon as she had said it, she felt that however warm his feelings were to her, he had not forgiven her for that.

column2: Yes, he said, "the letter was so strange.
column3: Yes, he said, "the letter was so strange.

column2: It was all the truth.
column3: It was all the truth.

column2: Yes, you do doubt it.	Yes, you do doubt it.
The duty of going to a concert...
column3: The duty of going to a concert...

column2: Why not talk about it? she said.
column3: Why not talk about it? she said.

column2: Oh, Anna, why are you so irritable?
column3: Oh, Anna, why are you so irritable?

column2: Anna, that's cruel.	Anna, that's cruel.
Either we must separate or else live together."
column3: Either we must separate or else live together."

column2: But for that..."
column3: But for that..."

column2: I will write to him.
column3: I will write to him.

column2: But I will come with you to Moscow."
column3: But I will come with you to Moscow."

column2: It was a moment's impression, but she never forgot it.
column3: It was a moment's impression, but she never forgot it.
